title: Fonts on christina aguilera "stripped album
content:
anyone know these two fonts, seen on christina aguilera's album?   
   
 ![stripped pic](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/3281.gif)   
   
cheers.

 [‹ Font ID](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/www.typophile.com/node/10601 "Go to previous forum topic") [WHAT IS THIS FONT ?!$?!! ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/www.typophile.com/node/10620 "Go to next forum topic")
author: anonymous

comments.content: The script suspiciously looks like the swash version of LetterPerfect's [Florens](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/F/FRSQ/F_FRSQ-10005000.jhtml). Long time I've seen this one in action, so I wouldn't know if these specific letterforms are present in the font. Adobe has an OpenType version, so these should be included. Couldn't find a character map though.

Though the serif looks very familiar, its name keeps eluding me. If you fail to get it identified, I'd recommend [Percolator](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/percolator/) or [Democratica](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/www.emigre.com/EF.php?fid=89) which are very similar in atmosphere and IMHO much better quality designs.
The script is not Florens, it's Zapfino.
Is it? I stand corrected. I haven't seen Zapfino's alternate characters in action yet, so I wouldn't know. Still no news from the serif...
[Fandango](http://web.archive.org/web/20081102022540/http:/66.70.183.115/fonts/fontshow/db.cgi?db=default&uid=default&ID=32933&ww=on&view_records=View%2BRecords) by Tom K. Sieu for T26.

Nice catch, John.   
But that took us almost a month - how embarassing... ;-)   
   
hhp
Thpppt. I only saw the thread today. I don't get paid for this, you know.
I wouldn't be so embarassed, Hrant. It's not exactly like it's the font design of the century IMHO. Look at that lowercase "r".

\> I don't get paid for this   
   
But thanks for doing it anyway.   
   
hhp

In this text-based world, a well placed emoticon (i.e. ;-)   
goes a long way.   
   
(As a side note, I also love how an emoticon can finish   
a parenthetical statement. Just like this one =)
Paul -- all comments thus far I agree with. But more importantly could you put this type into some sort of context? Maybe a specimen?
that lowercase k is still gorgeous. congratulations on your release, paul!
